title: plans-for-new-clubhouse-hotel-and-houses-at-dunbar-golf-club-set-to-be-submitted-this-summer
story: Discussions about a new clubhouse and hotel at the historic course, which dates back to , have been ongoing for more than a decade.Earlier this year, Dunbar Golf Club and CALA Management Ltd, who are behind the plans, revealed updated proposals, which also include about  homes.A public exhibition was held at the end of April ahead of a formal planning application being submitted in ldquolate summer early autumn.Tony Thomas, from APT Planning and Development Ltd, is representing the two organisations and was pleased to say more than  people had visited the public exhibition.The plans, as well as including a modern clubhouse and hotel, also feature a new driving range, nine-hole golf course, a golf academy and practice facilities.Mr Thomas said the general reaction towards the images of the proposed clubhouse was ldquobrilliant, with many asking when it would open.Concerns focused on public access versus membersrsquo rights, with a general concern about the level of development throughout the town.Mr Thomas stressed that plans for a development on the site dated back several years, with older proposals having been given the green light in .The new proposals, which will not impact on the future of the existing course, were building on the previously approved plans.Mr Thomas previously outlined the hope that a planning application could be with the local authority by September.If approved, the first houses would be built a year later, with the clubhouse built in  and opening the following year.About  new homes would be built on the site of the current clubhouse, with the majority further south-east.

title: costa-coffee-in-musselburgh-criticised-for-overflowing-bins
story: Ward councillor Stuart Currie took up the issue after complaints from residents about the litter problem at the rear of the outlet opposite the entrance to Musselburgh Burgh Primary School.He branded it ldquounacceptable but the company has apologised to residents and pledged it has taken steps to address the issue.Mr Currie said: ldquoI was contacted by constituents about this issue and took it up with council officers.ldquoI was pleased about the swt action taken by our council staff to ensure that the problem has been dealt with in the short term.ldquoWhat is important is that Costa continues to ensure they apply the very best standards in our town.He added that there were bags full of Costa cups, adding: ldquoTrade waste bins are supposed to be sealed to stop people throwing things into them. Get another binitrsquos overflowing.Mr Currie said that the situation had improved and assurances had been given that it would not happen again.He said a similar issue was raised about a year ago andit happened a third time, formal action should be taken by the council against Costa.Mr Currie acknowledged that the coffee chain generated jobs locally and added to Musselburgh High Street.But he stressed: ldquoIt is their responsibility to ensure they clear up their trade waste adequately.The anti-litter campaign group Donrsquot Mess With Mussy is also calling on the company to clean up its act.Organiser Melanie Roccio said there were wooden drink stirrers, Costa-branded sugar packets and paper cups on the ground near the bins when they were not overflowing.She said: ldquoAs a huge brand name, Costa need to do so much more and they have the resources to do it.ldquoThe issue has been reported to them multiple times over three years.A spokesperson for East Lothian Council said: ldquoWe have visited the location and stressed the need for arrangements to be made to clear the area. We understand a private waste contract is in place.ldquoWe will continue to monitor the situation.A Costa Coffee spokesperson said: ldquoAs the nationrsquos favourite coffee shop, we are continually working hard to ensure that we serve the needs of our local communities. We apologise to the local residents of Musselburgh and have taken the necessary steps to address this issue working alongside East Lothian Council.

title: section-a1-shut-overnight-week-roadworks
story: Maintenance work will be carried outovernight on the westboundA layby to Gladsmuir between pm and ameach nightfrom Sunday, July , till Sunday,August .A signed ersion will be in place.Traffic will exit the westbound A via Oaktree Junction westbound off-slip road to join the A and on to the B.From here, vehicles will travel to the westbound Gladsmuir Junction on-slip road to re-join the westbound A.This work, with a value of pound, will benefit around , vehicles using this routeeach day by improving the condition of the carriageway and reducing the need for further more extensive maintenance, said Amey, which is responsible for maintaining the A.This scheme has been planned in consultation with Transport Scotland, Traffic Scotland, the emergency services, Lothian Buses and East Lothian Council.

title: popular-teacher-retires-ross-high-school
story: Gordon Muchall, an additional support needsteacher at the Tranent secondary school, has been praised for his work encouraging outdoor education and giving young children new and positive opportunities.From Edinburgh, Gordon followed a dferent path to most teachers, having been a partner in a law firm and a Catholic priest before giving it up and following a career in teaching.He said: ldquoIt felt like quite a natural progression. I had a broad range of experiences to bring to the job.ldquoWhen I was a priest, I was chaplain at the Royal Infirmary of Edinburgh, dealing with people who were grieving, and I also visited special needs schools in Fe, and it was these visits that got me into teaching.ldquoLeaving the priesthood was a decision that I thought long and hard about, and in the end decided that it was the right move and I have no regrets. I trained as a teacher and got a job at Ross High over nine years ago.ldquoI was keen to bring a lot of outdoor learning to my work. I encouraged the children to climb hills, try kayaking and canoeing, rugby, things that a lot of the parents never thought their children could do.ldquoIrsquom a rugby referee as well, so naturally encouraged the children to play rugby, and to join the school choir and things.ldquoSeeing how happy they were and the smiles on their faces is something that I will really miss.Gordon is planning to move to the Isle of Mull to spend his retirement with his we.ldquoWersquore quite outdoorsy, we do a lot of hiking and kayaking, he said.ldquoOur house will be right on the waterfront, so I am very looking forward to it.ldquoIrsquove enjoyed myself, but I think itrsquos time for younger blood to take over, and I can give myself a rest!Jillian Binnie, depute head teacher ASN at Ross High, said: ldquoGordon has made a huge contribution to the ASN provision and Ross High School as a community, especially in driving the introduction of an outdoor education programme that allows all of our young people, even those with the most severe and complex needs, to take part.ldquoHe has a calm, non-judgemental approach to dealing with any challenges he might face on a daily basis.ldquoHe shows all of our young people unconditional positive regard and has built strong relationships with both our young people and their families. He is also a much-valued team member.ldquoWe all wish him well in his retirement.

title: calls-create-car-park-aldi-moves-new-site-haddington
story: Aldi is among the businesses named in a planning application for a retail park on Haddingtonrsquos western edge.Those proposals are still being weighed up by the council but,approved, it could see Aldi move from its current home off Whittingehame Drive to the new development at Gateside West.That would leave an empty site, with community councillors in the town suggesting that the council look into creating a new town centre car park there.Jan Wilson, chairwoman of Haddington and District Community Council, was among those backing the idea.She said: ldquoThat would be a great thing to happen because we are needing the spaces.ldquoEast Lothian Council have bought [the hospital site at] Herdmanflat and,they can buy over that, I hope they would be able to buy Aldi, although I am surprisedAldi were moving.Concerns about town centre parking have been raised on a regular basis, with fears that there are not enough spaces to ensure people can use the townrsquos businesses.Paul Darling, one of the community councilrsquos planning liaison officers, also felt it was worth weighing up the idea of transforming the site.He said: ldquoIf [the council] can buy it, that would be great.ldquoButsomebody is there saying it is a brand new shop and they can walk in, change the logo and open, they are going to put in a slightly higher bid than what the council can put in.Pat Lemmon, who works in the town centre, felt it was a good location for a potential car park.She said that changes planned for the town centre were suggesting parking spaces could be lost and an alternative ldquohad to be found.The community councillor told the Courier: ldquoI cannot see East Lothian Council giving up their car park or the long-stay car park at Tesco, which they seem to fill up first thing in the morning. Another car park has been mooted for a long time.However, echoing Mr Darlingrsquos view, she felt that it was more likely that another supermarket or retailer would move into the siteAldi decided to move.The town centre site has been home to a supermarket for more than  years, with Aldi setting up shop about a decade ago.When the plans for the retail park at Gateside West were lodged, the supermarket giants distanced themselves from any potential move, despite being named in the plans ndash along with coffee chain Costa and Home Bargains ndash as ldquoend occupiers confirmed for the site.A spokeswoman for Aldi said the new store was ldquonot currently on our radar.The Gateside development would be made up of three retail units, two restaurants cafes and a drive-thru takeaway, with Greggs and The Food Warehouse also linked.A petrol station and retail unit are also being earmarked for the site.Currently, the Aldi store site has more than  parking spaces but that number would increasethe supermarket building were demolished.A council spokeswoman said: ldquoThese are speculative comments and we believe that Aldi has dismissed rumours that they may move location.ldquoIn general terms, any changes of use to sites within Haddington would be open to consultation with local residents and businesses.

title: new-museum-exhibition-celebrates-history-musselburgh-festival
story: Past Honest Lads and Honest Lasses have rallied round with support by donating items of memorabilia for the display, which includes photographs of past events, riding boots, stirrups and a riding crop.The iety of gts presented by local industries and the community to Honest Lads and Honest Lasses at sashing ceremonies can been seen, as well as trophies for events such as the Honest Ladsrsquo Race, Ladiesrsquo Race and Crusaders Riding Club competition.There is a chance to get a close-up look at sashes embroidered with the names of every Honest Lad and Honest Lass from  to  and the Burgh Standard, which plays an important role during the annual festival.Official outfits worn by the Honest Lad and Honest Lass are exhibited, as well as programmes, pennants, the first minute book for festival organisers the Honest Tounrsquos Association and words for the Musselburgh Song. Information is on show about the carriage used on election night, when the official party is transported through local streets to waving crowds.The birth of the festival in , when Jimmy Arthur was Honest Lad and Ina Vass, Honest Lass, is also outlined.This yearrsquos Honest Lad Aidan Maguire, Honest Lass Claire Dougal and attendant Abbie Thomson were amongst the first to enjoy a tour of the exhibition after their recent visits to local primary schools and Musselburgh Grammar School.Stefanie Talac, honorary secretary of the Honest Tounrsquos Association , said this was the first exhibition about the festival at the museum and they hoped that as many people as possible would pay it a visit.She said: ldquoWe are delighted at the way the exhibition has turned out. We had a lot of help from past Honest Lads and Honest Lassies.ldquoThere is a beautully bound photograph album from the Honest Lass of  which was presented by the local paper mill. Our th year Honest Lass was presented with a travel iron from Brunton Wire Mill. The connection with the fishing community in Musselburgh is also shown in the gts with a ship in a bottle and model boats.She added: ldquoDuring the festival, the Honest Lass pins a pennant to the top of the flag and it has the Honest Ladrsquos name on it. Each pennant is in the museum as well.Stefanie said that while the festival is on from July  to  this year, some of the display items will be removed as they will have a part to play in the event itself, before being ed to the museum afterwards.She added: ldquoThe museum is a great asset to the town. We are really pleased that we have had the opportunity to have the exhibition in the museum. It is the first since the museumrsquos inception and hopefully we will do so again in the future. The exhibition is here for people who want to learn more about the festival and we hope they do.The museum at  High Street is open Thursday to Saturday, .am to pm.

title: tim-39-s-tales-naming-new-town
story: WHAT is history  It isnrsquot actually what happened in the past. History is the way we view and see things that happened in the past. That view is limited by a number of factors. The availability of surviving records and evidence is one.The vast majority of what happened in the past is inevitably lost to us. This is true even for our own personal memories. So history is the small tip of the iceberg of events and times gone by, brought to the surface by the survival of some accounts more than others.And these records are never unbiased. Often historical records and evidence are purposely partial, influenced by ideology and personal allegiances. But all are biased in some way, as the limited viewpoint and interests of those recording events is based on their experience or motives.As a result, we can only see historical events through a narrow keyhole, with most characters and goings on out of view. Itrsquos the common people who are most always invisible in history. Our own ideological preference and belief in what is important will then affect how we interpret the limited evidence we have.This is why history is often subject to furious debate, and rightly so. Irsquod say itrsquos almost impossible not to allow our own perspectives, interests and values to influence the way we interpret the broader meaning of historical events and their signicance for contemporary society.Such a debate is being had in East Lothian just now, as to the name of the new town to be built on the Blindwells site, between Prestonpans and Longniddry and just to the north of Gladsmuir and Tranent.The name can be romantically translated to mean lsquohidden springsrsquo and it was across this once-marshy ground that the Jacobites crept stealthily at night to mount a surprise attack on the Redcoats on September , . That famous battle lasted  minutes and was a victory for the Jacobites, and the launchpad of Bonnie Prince Charliersquos march into England.Consequently, the Scottish Battlefields Trust has submitted a petition, as reported in the Courier last week, to name the new community Charlestoun and build a statue of Charles.When I was at school, he seemed a dashing and heroic figure. The songs and stories about him are infectious and I totally understand how the stories told about him have created a romantic and thrilling image.But then I studied the topic in more depth, at both university and afterwards. The period has suffered from the romantic treatment but there are fascinating stories of loyalty and sacrice to a man who, in reality, saw the common people chiefly as cannon fodder for his personal and family ambitions.It is for this reason I feel there are enough name places and statues to aristocratic and powerful men whose main historical role was to make and wage war, evenhe has a famous and romantic reputation.This is not to say we shouldnrsquot remember the fascinating history of the area, including that fateful day of battle when the Jacobites crossed the land.But itrsquos how we commemorate it and who we include. What makes the Jacobite period truly fascinating is the tapestry of stories of the many people involved, on both sides. It was a brutal time, in which there was certainly deep loyalty on both sides, but there were many other reasons why people found themselves on one side or the other. It was a brutal civil war, brought on by the aspirations of the exiled Stuarts.Do we commemorate the memory of the man who caused that war or do we commemorate those who were caught up in it  Is it really the case thatwe do the former we do the latter  Irsquom not convinced.There are other stories to consider of course for the site. There was coal mining there for generations. The lives of mining families, men, women and children who toiled in horric conditions, still remains mostly unheralded by history. Maybe itrsquos not lsquoromanticrsquo enough. Likewise with farming, which was a constant economic activity in the area for generations.There was also another unusual underground activity on the site after the early mine closed. Smugglers made an illegal whisky still deep down in the mine shaft once it was disused. It took a while for the customs men to realise East Lothian had an illicit whisky-making enterprise deep below ground in the old mine workings. When they finally raided the mine, they found the still, but no sign of the makers of the whisky. It kind of gives new meaning to the name lsquohidden springsrsquo!It is suggested the children in schools should have the final say in the new name, which is a great idea. But let our children be introduced to all aspects of our local history and allow them to understand how the way history is taught influences what we believe is important in contemporary society as well, and that there is no lsquocorrectrsquo view on this.Irsquod love to be part of that discussion and debate.

title: parents-launch-petition-school-bus-operator-change
story: Families whose children attend two secondary schools in East Lothian were stunned to discover that local firm PrenticeCoaches would no longer be used to transport the youngsters when schoolsafter the summer.The news was broken to them by Prentice, which is based in Haddington, last week, sparking a furious reaction from a number of parents.Now a petition has been launched calling for Prentice to have the contract, which has allegedly been awarded to a rival firm, given back.One mother whose children attend Knox Academy in Haddingtonand are bussed in from Gford said that she was shocked by the news.She said: ldquoPrentice have been looking after our children for  years and they are being replaced with no consultation or discussion.ldquoParents know the drivers and trust them to look after their children.ldquoIt is beyond belief that the council would simply put a dferent company in place without even consulting with the families affected.A petition calling for theof Prentice has collected more than  signatures since it was launched online.It says: ldquoPrentice provide a community service where parents feel reassured and comfortable putting their children on the buses.ldquoWe believe East Lothian [Council] has chosen to put cost over service and safety.ldquoThere is absolutely nothing wrong with the current service.ldquoThis is simply a cost-cutting exercise which could potentially put our children at risk.Prentice provided bus services for Knox Academy and North Berwick High School but has now lost the contract for those services.Ross Prentice, the company boss, admitted that he was ldquodisappointed by the councilrsquos decision.The company said: ldquoIt is a sad day. We have operated the Knox routes continuously for over  years.ldquoWe would like to thank all the pupils and parents who we have transported over the years for being so friendly and their excellent behaviour, and wish the current pupils all the best for their futures.A spokesman for East Lothian Council said: ldquoAs the previous contract had expired, the council was required to carry out an open procurement process to appoint an operator for the service.ldquoAs the contract is yet to be formally awarded, we cannot provide further detail at this stage.ldquoHowever, we can assure families that tenders have been assessed in line with all requirements, standard procedure and quality criteria. In the event of a new operator being appointed, other aspects of the service will be unchanged.The petition can be found at you.degrees.org.uk petitions reinstate-prentice-buses-as-knox-academy-school-transport-provider

title: bbc-show-broadcast-live-east-lothian-evening
story: Foxlake Adventures plays host to the BBC Scotland Adventure Show, which will be streaming live for only the second time ever from the wakeboarding park, near West Barns.The show, which starts at pm, is hosted by Dougie Vipond, Lauren MacCallum and Patrick Winterton.Paul McGreal, organiser, said: ldquoLeave the stresses and strains of the working week behind you and come and watch something fast and furious at the amazing Foxlake Adventures. This is off-road triathlon like yoursquove never seen it before!ldquoThe course will be short wersquore aiming for winning times of around - minutes. Either way, this should be fun.The course covers approximately m open-water swim in the private, freshwater wakeboard park, then a k mountain bike section and a k trail run.The BBC are inviting members of the public to cheer on the participants, though there will be no vehicle access after pm there is no charge.

title: woman-found-nearly-three-times-drink-driving-limit
story: Jacqueline Johnstone, of St Germains Terrace, was caught drink-driving at Gilbert Avenue in North Berwick.Johnstone, , was found to have mg of alcohol in ml of breath during the incident ndash the legal limit is mg.She appeared at Edinburgh Sherf Court, where she pleaded guilty to the offence, which took place on May .Sherf Pamela Bowman banned Johnstone from driving for  months and fined her pound.She was allowed to take part in a drink-driving rehabilitation scheme which could reduce her ban by a quarter.

title: north-berwick-high-school-roll-set-top-1-000-extension-planned
story: The school, which welcomes pupils from the surrounding villages as well as North Berwick, currently has a school roll of .However, that figure is expected to increase, with the town continuing to grow and the school set to become the fourth secondary school in the county with more than , pupils.Three extensions ndash in ,  and  ndash have already been carried out on the school to accommodate the growth of the town.Now, the proposed extension would cater for a school roll of up to ,.Plans submitted to East Lothian Council note: ldquoThe completed building will provide state-of-the-art teaching and social space facilities in line with the clientrsquos brief as well as promoting energy efficiency and offering facilities which signal the high value placed on learning at North Berwick High School.ldquoThe project is to reflect the standards commensurate with a modern school facility and provide a high-quality environment that will inspire both staff and young people to achieve their full potential.The proposed extension would occupy an area to the south-west of the existing buildings, bordered by the synthetic pitch and the site boundary with the schoolrsquos neighbours Law Primary School.The document states: ldquoThe location of the proposed extension will offer views out over the sports pitches and towards North Berwick Law.The ground floor of the three-storey extension will become home to the home economics department, with a shared social and exhibition space.Social sciences will be based on the first floor, with the languages department on the second floor and ldquolarge shared breakout spaces at the heart of the floorplan.The plans from Innovate East Lothian Ltd, which is acting on behalf of East Lothian Council, could go before the local authorityrsquos planning committee later this year.Currently, Dunbar Grammar School , Musselburgh Grammar Schooland Ross High Schoolin Tranent all have more than , pupils.

title: council-remove-recycling-wheelie-bins-contamination
story: East Lothian Council is one of the few local authorities in Scotland to retain recycling boxes for most of its households and has a  per cent recycling rate ndash higher than the national average.However, Tom Reid, the councilrsquos head of infrastructure, revealed that it had rolled out , communal recycling bins in small communities and densely populated streets.But, he said, the result had been a much higher contamination level in the recycled waste which suggested thatbins were rolled out across the county it could cost the council up to poundmillion. The bins, first used in , are now being removed by the council and replaced with inidual boxes.Mr Reid told a meeting of the councilrsquos policy and performance review committee that the bins had not been a success.Councillor Gordon Mackett asked why wheelie bins could not be used, saying he was told by people they ldquowould recycle morethey had wheelie bins.But Mr Reid said: ldquoUsing the boxes produces a higher quality of recycling waste and we currently sell it for up to pound,.ldquoWe have , wheelie bins out there and the result has been a disappointing  to  per cent contamination.ldquoIf we moved to wheelie bins we would have to pay out between poundmillion to poundmillion to decontaminate the materials.A council spokesperson said the recycling bins had already been removed from some parts of the county, with the rest expected to be replaced by boxes in the near future.

title: stars-music-sport-tv-head-east-lothian-scottish-open-pro-am
story: The Aberdeen Standard Investments Scottish Open gets under way next Thursday , with some of the worldrsquos top golfers looking to gain momentum heading into The Open.Twenty-four hours before competition gets under way, Tartan Wednesday s to the competition, along with the Pro-Am tournament.Fans are encouraged to join players and celebrities by donning tartan in aid of the tournament charities: My Namersquo Doddie Foundation, Leuchie House and the European Tour Foundation.Television presenters Dan Walker and Naga Munchetty, who regularly share the sofa on BBC Breakfast, will be joined by TV personality and regular Hero Challenge host Vernon Kay.Frontman for Scottish rock band Twin Atlantic Sam McTrusty is joined by comedian-turned-radio presenter Fred MacAulay and talkSPORT presenter Georgie Bingham.Staying in sport, Winter Olympian Eve Muirhead will also join what promises to be a fun day out on the golf course.In a battle of the Irish boy bands, Boyzone singer Keith Duffy and singer-songwriter and former Westle vocalist Brian McFadden will also tee it up.Former Scotland and British Lions lock forward Doddie Weir revealed in June  that he had been diagnosed with motor neurone disease. In November that year, he and his trustees launched the My Namersquo Doddie Foundation to raise funds to aid research into the causes of motor neurone disease and investigate potential cures.Leuchie House, near North Berwick, is Scotlandrsquos only dedicated respite centre and offers caring respite breaks to people with long-term neurological conditions, including motor neurone disease.By providing the care they need, Leuchie is able to support people with many dferent conditions to have fulfilling, revitalising breaks, while giving their carers time away from caring.The two charities joined the European Tour Foundation ndash which works with charities, players, governing bodies and partners to ensure a lasting legacy in the countries where the European Tour plays ndash as official charity partners of the Scottish Open in , and will once again benefit from a range of fundraising activities throughout tournament week, including Tartan Wednesday.The Aberdeen Standard Investments Scottish Open is being played for the first time at The Renaissance Club, which was founded in  and nestles on  picturesque acres along the Firth of Forth. Tickets for the Pro-Am are pound for adults and pound for juniors.

title: kind-pupils-help-raise-money-beach-wheelchairs-project
story: Youngsters at The Compass School collected an impressive pound. through an enterprise sale at the Haddington school, with the money going to North Berwick-based Beach Wheelchairs.The schoolrsquos pupil council identied the good cause as one of the three main charities to support throughout the year.Beach wheelchairs enable people with disabilities to access the beach through using specially designed wheelchairs created to travel over the sand and even into the water.The scheme was first set up in  and, since then, similar facilities have been established in Portobello and at Seton Sands.The enterprise sale, which took place before the end of the schoolrsquos term, saw children designing and making a range of dferent items, from artwork to baking and from origami creations to practical items to use at home.The sale followed on from a successful Swimathon earlier this year, with youngsters ing in to raise funds for WaterAid.Mark Becher, headmaster at the school on West Road, was proud of the pupils.He said: ldquoI was delighted when the children of our pupil council chose Beach Wheelchairs as one of the principle charities they would be supporting this year.ldquoThe charity does so much fantastic work and has opened up the beautul beaches of East Lothian for those who previously had very restricted access or none at all. The children greatly enjoyed creating and making for the enterprise sale, which saw a vast range of goods for sale.ldquoTo achieve this total is testament to their efforts and the generosity of all those who supported them.ldquoWe would like to thank everyone who assisted the children in this very successful initiative.Last week, a group of staff and children from the pupil council visited Melanie Kay at Beach Wheelchairsrsquo facility in North Berwick.The children had the opportunity to view all of the wheelchairs and to meet with a family who had travelled from the west of Scotland in order to use a wheelchair.The pupils spoke to the family about the benefits of the charity and they all observed the importance of these chairs first-hand.

title: princess-anne-makes-special-visit-leuchie-house
story: EAST Lothian played host to a distinguished guest as the Princess Royal made a special visit to the county.Her Royal Highness Princess Anne paid a visit to Leuchie House, the respite care centre near North Berwick which offers respite breaks for people with a iety of long-term conditions as well as their carers, last Thursday.The Princess Royal previously visited Leuchie in  and launched the lsquoLeuchie Forever Fundrsquo, a new fundraising initiative for the charity, of which she became patron. She also visited in .On her latest visit, the Princess ndash who was described as a ldquolovely lassie by one guest ndash was greeted by Mark Bevan, chief executive, and Bob Brannan, chair of the fund, and taken to meet Leuchiersquos guests, staff, supporters, patrons and trustees.The meeting was held in Leuchiersquos lounge, with a series of paintings hanging on the walls created by Rachel Mylne, who had turned  two days prior to the royal visit.Money raised by the Leuchie Forever Fund had allowed the lounge to be redecorated, and when hanging the paintings on the wall a signature from the s, a mark from a previous painter, was discovered.On her arrival at Leuchie, Princess Anne first met some of the guests and their carers. She asked questions including ldquoHow did you find out about this place  and ldquoHow long have you been coming here  She listened to their stories and the dference Leuchie had made in their lives.Moving on to the trustees, donors and patrons, she was interested in hearing how they had discovered Leuchie and how they had become involved in the charity.Among those present was Scottish rugby legend Gavin Hastings, who is also a patron of Leuchie.Describing his involvement in the charity, he said: ldquoItrsquos a great place to come along and itrsquos great to support the work that they do here because they do such great work ndash not just here in Leuchie but all over Scotland.After meeting the Princess, many praised her humour and willingness to take the time and talk to everyone, listening to their stories. Others mentioned how hardworking and well-briefed she was and how much she knew about Leuchie.Regular guest Iain Elder described the Princess as ldquoa lovely lassie, while others praised her interest and passion for the charity.Jim Maxwell, who is the primary carer for we Jane, a guest at Leuchie, said of his conversation with the Princess: ldquoShe asked where we lived and how we managed to find Leuchie House. I told her as a carer it is very important for the both of us to come here.ldquoShe really took the time to speak to us and hear our story.Afterwards, some of the guests gave a speech where they explained how much Leuchie House had helped them.Alex MacCarthy-Morrogh has multiple sclerosis and visits Leuchie every Tuesday as a day guest. As well as attending physio and fitness classes, which he describes as essential for his physical and mental wellbeing, he talks to fellow guests to keep them company.He said: ldquoI come here to help myself and to give my we a break and give her some freedom. Me being here, she knows Irsquom safe which is very important to me.ldquoThis place is important to the people here, therersquos no other place like it. They treat you like a person and see you beyond the wheelchair.His we Susie said: ldquoItrsquos great when Alex comes here. Falling is his biggest concern and I donrsquot worry he is going to fall when he is here. Him being safe is so important to me and they really look after him and everyone here.Mairi OrsquoKeefe, patron and former chief executive of Leuchie House, said: ldquoPrincess Anne loves the work we do here and the respiratory things that we do everyone gets physio and everyone gets a respiratory assessment. She also sees what it does for the guests.ldquoShe really cares about Leuchie.A tour of Leuchie followed, with Princess Anne meeting one volunteer who wrote the calligraphy on the invites and who gave the Princess a humorous wink.When speaking to the dieticians, Princess Anne expressed how dficult it must be to keep up with a iety of dferent diets.She took an interest in one, a soon-to-be graduate, asking about her experience in Leuchie in relation to her studies and saying: ldquoYoursquove probably come across more diets here than on your course!Her tour led on to the art room, while in the TV room Princess Anne met one guest who had been coming to Leuchie since , jokingly saying: ldquoYoursquore keeping them on their toes!The Princess was taken into a further lounge and met a man taking part in a virtual reality experience.When she noticed he was in London, she said: ldquoI know London very well. She was told he caught a whale earlier ndash ldquonot in the Thames, I hope, she replied.Mark Bevan, chief executive of Leuchie, said: ldquoWe were thrilled to welcome HRH The Princess Royal, and patron of the Leuchie Forever Fund, to Leuchie House once again and for her to meet and thank our many supporters.ldquoShe saw first-hand the importance of providing quality respite to our guests and their carers.ldquoThe visit was a wonderful experience for our guests and colleagues who were able to spend time with Her Royal Highness. She spoke to them about their experiences and the dference that spending time at Leuchie makes to their lives and those of their carers.Bob Brannan, chairman of the Leuchie Forever Fund, said: ldquoThe Princess has taken time since becoming our patron three years ago to really understand Leuchie.ldquoToday as on previous occasions, she has used this understanding to encourage our many generous supporters to ensure Leuchie can continue to develop and provide such a great service to so many people across Scotland for years to come.As the visit came to an end, the Princess signed the visitorsrsquo book and was presented flowers and a card by Rachel Mylne, who said: ldquoThank you for all your hard work, we are very grateful. Leuchie is a wonderful place, will you try and keep it going Princess Anne replied: ldquoI will definitely try my best.

title: thousands-expected-attend-aberdeen-standard-investments-scottish-open-renaissance-club

title: new-homes-over-60s-longniddry-welcomed
story: East Lothian Council gave the go-ahead for nearly  new houses in three separate applications to its planning committee.One application for four houses and  flats revealed that all its units would be for older people.The housing, which is on land identied for potentially having up to  new homes on it, to the south of Longniddry, will be taken by Castle Rock Edin Housing Association once built.A planning application before the committee revealed: ldquoAll of the residential units would be for independent living for people aged over  years.The flats will mainly be in two-storey buildings, with one three-storey building and four bungalows which will be built around a courtyard-style quadrangle.Two additional applications included one for  houses and  flats, all of which will be for private sale, and another for  houses and  flats, of which only two houses and eight flats will be affordable.Places for People, which is overseeing the over-s housing and  private properties, welcomed the decision as the ldquofirst phase in the Longniddry South development.Willie Lockhart, Places for People interim director of development for Scotland, said: ldquoWe are delighted to have the go-ahead to begin building at Longniddry. It promises to be a truly special development offering benefits to both new and existing residents of the village.The layout of the development, on land owned by the Wemyss and March Estate, sees housing designed by architect Ben Pentreath to reflect traditional East Lothian homes, and the committee was shown a walkthrough video depicting what the streets will look like.Ward councillor Lachlan Bruce said: ldquoI welcome the decision to provide affordable housing for over-s in Longniddry.ldquoIt is an issue for people wanting to downsize from their properties which are then freed up for families who want to move in.Representatives of Longniddry Community Council attended the meeting to raise concerns about some of the infrastructure surrounding the new housing. But they told the committee they had no objections to the development itself.Councillor Norman Hampshire, planning convenor, encouraged the community council to contact the local authority with any concerns about issues during the development of the new housing.And council leader Willie Innes praised the members of the community council for attending.He said: ldquoThe community council raise valid concern which will need to be addressed by the developers. They are not opposing it in principle and we want to work with the community to manage the process.He added: ldquoI think this development is something special and something dferent and will make a positive impact on Longniddry and East Lothian.Rock Feilding-Mellen, from Socially Conscious Capital, which worked with the landowners to develop a masterplan for the entire site, welcomed the plansrsquo approval.He said: ldquoWe are thrilled that Zero C can now start building these much-needed new homes and turning our carefully designed masterplan and design code into a beautul st-century extension to Longniddry.ldquoWe trust that residents and members of the wider community who contributed throughout the many consultations will feel that their time and effort has paid off when they finally get to see the results.

title: knox-academy-half-marathon-team-raise-2-000

title: bid-third-pharmacy-tranent-turned
story: The application was presented to the Pharmacy Practice Committee , which decided that the town was already suitably served by its current pharmacies.The committee also stated that there was too Lloyds Pharmacy and Well Tranent, both on High Street ndash were present at the committee hearing and both claimed that they had already addressed any issues that were raised in the consultation and therefore problems raised by the CAR were no longer applicable.There was also a question over whether the premises planned for the new pharmacy at  Bridge Street would be large enough to support the planned two consultation rooms and dispensary area, which the committee felt raised the issue of whether appropriate confidentiality was possible.Letters of support for the pharmacy were submitted by met.Pharmacy applicant Niamh Morrison visited the community council to thank members for their support over the process and to assure them that she would be launching an appeal.She said: ldquoI am of course very disappointed.ldquoI really believe that this community needs this, and I have developed a real soft spot for the area.ldquoThe appeal process unfortunately wonrsquot be quick, it could take years.ldquoI just wanted to thank you all for the support that you have given us.The rejection comes not long after Tranent Medical Practice announced that it would be suspending advanced title: pictures-regiment-receives-historic-honour-parading-dunbar
story: Members of the public lined the streets in Dunbar on Saturday as a special presentation and parade took place to mark the historic moment involving the Lothians and Border Yeomanry.The regimentrsquos links with East Lothian date back to  with the formation of the East Lothian Yeomanry Cavalry.The Dunbar, Seton, Salton and Gford troops eventually disbanded and joined with other areas before reforming in  under the current name.Councillor Jim Goodfellow, East Lothian Councilrsquos Armed Forces Champion, conferred the Freedom of East Lothian to the Yeomanry, represented by Major Stuart Vine, in the shadow of Lauderdale House, the Regimentrsquos original home.Mr Goodfellow, who represents the North Berwick Coastal ward, said: ldquoAs well as being a landmark building on Dunbarrsquos High Street, Lauderdale House is the historic home of the Lothians and Border Yeomanry.ldquoIt is therefore appropriate that we are celebrating this occasion here in its shadow.ldquoThe Freedom of East Lothian is the highest honour our council can award.ldquoIt recognises those who play an important role here: those who represent our county and its values, contribute to the fabric of our civic society or who are integral to the history and tradition of East Lothian.ldquoIn granting the Freedom to the Lothians and Border Yeomanry today, the Regiment joins the Royal Scots Borderers st Battalion, renowned artist John Bellany and golf champion Catriona Matthew as worthy recipients of this rarely-bestowed tribute.ldquoLast weekend, our nation came together to commemorate Armed Services Day, which marks the important part that the Armed Services have played, and continue to play, in our society.ldquoToday we come together as a county to pay our particular thanks to the members of the Lothians and Border Yeomanry for the part it has played in East Lothian since its earliest roots as the East Lothian Yeomanry Cavalry in .ldquoIt is extraordinary to think that the regiment has represented East Lothian in every conflict since the Napoleonic Wars, including the Great War.Following the presentation, the regiment paraded along Dunbarrsquos High Street, saluting Mr Goodfellow outside the Town House, before continuing on to its war memorial outside Dunbar Parish Church on the townrsquos Queenrsquos Road for a rededication ceremony.Representatives from the council, serving and veteran members of the Armed Services community and their families, support organisations and crowds of well-wishers witnessed the occasion.Granting the Freedom of East Lothian to the regiment recognises the sacrices and service made by its members over the years, and reinforces the councilrsquos commitment to all armed services members living within the county.Major SJ Vine, Squadron Leader, ESquadron, The Scottish and North Irish Yeomanry, said the squadron was ldquotruly honoured to be given the Freedom of East Lothian.He added: ldquoThe day marks the reinvigoration of the strong partnership between the community and the squadron from which many of those serving, have served or represented through our long history and antecedent regiments live and work ndash we are grateful for the enduring support.ldquoIt is signicant and fitting that we are able to parade through Dunbar and also rededicate the war memorial in what is our spiritual home.ldquo[It was] a truly proud and memorable day and one which reconnects the lsquoCountyrsquos Regimentrsquo with the community whom we serve.The presentation and parade were part of a day of celebration of the regiment and Armed Services held in the town.A civic reception was held at the Town House for the Yeomanry and its supporters where a framed lsquoFreedom of East Lothianrsquo certicate was presented.The British Legion hosted a family event at its club for  people, while Dunbar Museum hosted a special one-day exhibition of the Yeomanryrsquos military treasures.

title: car-submerged-tide-north-berwick-beach
story: The incident, which took place on Sunday, required the assistance of the townrsquos RNLI, who had to tow the car out using their leboat tractor.The incident attracted plenty of attention, with many people stopping to take a look at the car being recovered.Eyewitness Derek Braid said: ldquoThe problem started when the owner of the car was recovering a RIB from the sea.ldquoThe car became stuck on the soft sand on the beach at the West Bay and the incoming tide engulfed the car.When the RNLI arrived, crew members attached a rope from the tractor to the car.After a number of attempts and plenty of pushing by the leboat crew and the other people nearby, the car was eventually successfully towed out of the water and taken to safety on the Elcho Green slipway.

title: degree-delight-ex-leuchie-chief
story: Mairi OrsquoKeefe was awarded a lsquoDegree of Doctor of the University, Honoris Causarsquo at a graduation ceremony in the Usher Hall in Edinburgh on Tuesday.She celebrated alongside Prue Leith, The Great British Bake Off judge and chancellor at Musselburgh-based QMU.Mairi is the former chief executive of Leuchie House, a respite care centre near North Berwick that provides care for those suffering from long-term neurological conditions and their families.She took over the helm at Leuchie in  when it was operated by the MS Society however, this was not her first experience in management as she has held ious airport manager and change manager roles.She helped save the centre from closure in  after setting up the lsquoSave Leuchiersquo campaign and building support for the centre.The campaign gained enough backing to allow Leuchie to become an independent charity.Over the next seven years, Mairi and her team secured pound. million in grants from trust funds and donations from members of the public, as well as support from the Scottish Government, delivering more than , respite nights.Mairi sat on cross-party groups in the Scottish Parliament, was vice-chair of the Health and Social Alliance Scotland and a member of the Governing Council for Edinburgh Chamber of Commerce.In  she was awarded lsquoCommunity Champion of the yearrsquo in STVrsquos lsquoFinding Scotlandrsquos Real Heroesrsquo awards. Two years later, she received an MBE for services to people with disabilities.Mairi has helped establish an official partnership with QMU, which has been in place since . The partnership has allowed for clinical and work placements, research and creative opportunities to be provided to many students, including nurses, film students, dietetics, physiotherapy and gastronomy.Mairi announced her retirement last year.Professor Petra Wend, principal and vice-chancellor of QMU, said: ldquoWe are delighted that our students had the opportunity to learn about the career of this former nursing and social care leader and to be inspired by her achievements and her compassion for others.ldquoWe are proud to recognise Mairi as a hard-working advocate for people living with disabilities across Scotland and beyond.ldquoWe celebrated her achievements as a leader and her success in integrating healthcare with respite services.

title: construction-work-waste-incinerator-near-dunbar-now-complete
story: Final tests are being carried out at the energy recovery facilityat Oxwellmains, with low-carbon energy already being generated at the site, to the south-west of Dunbar.The completion of Viridorrsquos ERF marks the latest milestone in a project delivering a , tonne per year energy recovery facility to Scotland.A key part of the poundm investment by Viridor in Scotland, the ERF will ert non-recyclable waste from landfill in line with the Scottish Governmentrsquos ambitions and contribute to Scottish energy security.More than  contractors put in more than two-million man hours to the project, with more than  workers on site at its peak.Scott Reynolds, Dunbar ERF operations manager, said that the site had already started generating low-carbon energy for the national grid and, over the course of the coming year, would create MW of base-load low-carbon energy direct to the electricity grid.The energy generated ndash which, according to Viridor, is comparable to  wind turbines ndash is enough to continuously power , homes.Mr Reynolds said: ldquoViridor is pleased to be working with the Scottish local authorities and businesses to put non-recyclable waste to work.ldquoWith the construction phase of the project now complete, we are carrying out final plant testing as we process non-recyclable waste, using this as the fuel to create electricity.ldquoThe new facility includes a visitorsrsquo centre, where we look forward to welcoming interested groups to encourage the next generation to put the right stuff in the right bin.ldquoWe will be talking about recycling here at the plant because we want to ensure valuable recycling opportunities are not missed.ldquoThe waste which comes here should only be waste which cannot be recycled, allowing us to attach a purpose to it through energy recovery.The plant is constructed on , piles, or vertical foundations, upon which sit more than , tonnes of concrete and steel to support the processing equipment of the -metre-high building.The facility features two boilers, each processing  tonnes of waste each hour, and managed and controlled through km of pipework and km of cabling.Waste received at Dunbar ERF will include residual household waste from East Lothian Council, as well as the local authorities in North and South Lanarkshire, in addition to non-recyclable commercial collections from Edinburgh and the Lothians.

title: big-yins-greatest-ever-comedy-routines-published-first-time
story: The comic has agreed a deal with a publisher for a new book called Tall Tales And Wee Stories which will feature classic yarns such as The Last Supper, Jojoba Shampoo, Incontinence Pants and Shouting at Wildebeest.Despite a -year stand-up career, the stories he tells on stage have not previously been released in written form.The book will be published in October by Two Roads.It comes after the Big Yin, who is suffering from Parkinsonrsquos disease, announced his retirement from stand-up last December.:Sir Billy Connolly chants with Glaswegians in New YorkConnolly, , will be writing a new introduction for the book, which will be illustrated by his artwork.He said: ldquoI was a storyteller long before I was a comedian. Coming from Glasgow, itrsquos weird, I donrsquot really tell jokes, like Irish jokes and all that, I tell wee stories.ldquoIrsquove been asked many times to put them down in a book and Irsquove always refused.ldquoIt didnrsquot seem right because as long as I was still performing live then I was still playing around with my stories ndash pulling them apart, twisting them around, improvising and improving.ldquoBut in December of last year, I decided to retire from live stand-up. So, this feels like the right moment to put these stories down, once and for all. Itrsquos always been a pleasure talking to you. I hope now itrsquoll be a pleasure reading me.The blurb for the book reads: ldquoBillyrsquos routines always felt spontaneous. He improvised, embellished and digressed as he went: a two-minute anecdote could become a -minute routine by the next night of a tour. And he brought a beautul sense of the absurd to his shows as he rfed on holidays, alcohol, the crucixion, or naked bungee jumping.For all your breaking Glasgow news, click here, or head to our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram pagesldquoBut Billyrsquos comedy could be laced with anger too. He hated pretentiousness and called out hypocrisy where ever he saw it.ldquoHe loved to shock, and his startling appearance gave him license to say anything he damn well pleased about sex, politics or religion. It was only because he was so likeable that he got it away. Billy had the popular touch. His comedy spanned generations and dferent social tribes in a way that few others have ever managed.Nick Davies, managing director at John Murray Press who acquired the rights for publishing house Two Roads, said: ldquoAs his many millions of fans will know, Billyrsquos stories can be rude, warm-hearted, anarchic, joyful, angry, far-fetched, down-to-earth and everything in between.ldquoThey are also beautully constructed, brilliantly paced and deeply funny.

title: Iain Macwhirter  You   ll have had your Indyref2 - the Tory leadership contest has made clear the gloves are coming off
story: Actually, what she told Nicola Sturgeon in March  was that ldquonow is not the time for Indyref, which is rather softer than the hard line her would-be successors are taking. Now its never. A flat no. Forget it. Youll have had your referendum.Both Boris and Hunt made clear at the Perth Hustings that there will be no independence referendum, eventhe SNP win outright in . Thats a sobering message for the independence movement, and for Nicola Sturgeon. She still regards the Section  route to a legally-binding referendum as the only plausible one. That is now road-blocked.There has been a dramatic hardening of rhetoric against Scotland during this campaign. Theresa May came to Stirling to proclaim that Nicola Sturgeon ldquocannot be trusted. That the Scottish government is incapable of negotiating ldquoin good faith. Why, Sturgeon had the temerity to portray the UK governments takeover of powers repatriated from Brussels as a ldquopower grab. You just cant deal with these people, May concluded.We all know what Boris Johnson thinks about Scotland. A nation of ldquofreeloaders. He described Scotland having free care and free tuition as ldquopretty monstrous. Jeremy Hunt has tended to be more emollient, but on Friday his gloves came off too. He condemned the Scottish Government as: ldquothe most bullying, isive, duplicitous, anti-business government Scotland has ever seen.Given that the Scottish National Party dominates the opinion polls, and has more seats in both parliaments than all the Unionist parties put together, this could be taken as an oblique criticism of the Scottish voter. I mean, are Scots so stupid that they dont realise they are being run by bullying charlatans  Its almost asthey cant be trusted to know their best interests, deluded as they are by the hypnotic rhetoric of separatism.This was all rather redolent of how British imperialists, like Churchill, used to talk about nationalist leaders in the old British colonies. They were all wily demagogues, up to no good. Cant trust them as far as you can throw them. The subtext was: the only language they understand is firmness. Just tell them what the score is and let them get on with it.This is very much the line taken in the Dailylast week by the Thatcherite former Scottish Secretary, Lord Forsyth of Drumlean. He says that the real threat to the Union comes from ldquogiving in to Nationalists demands. The Tories best bet is to tell them politely but firmly that they can stick their independence up their Great Glen ndash or words to that effect.All this is, of course, exactly what the SNP want to hear. There is nothing better for drumming up support for the Nationalist cause than hearing a phalanx of crusty Tory grandees telling Scotland to like the Union or lump it. Support for independence is creeping up ndash slowly but steadily ndash and is now % in the latest polls, and %Boris Johnson wins.True, demand for an early referendum on Scottish independence is certainly muted. But after Mr Johnson enters Number Ten ndash a racing certainty according to the latest YouGov poll ndash and a no deal Brexit looms, things could move fast. The SNP expect support for Yes, which has been stuck for five years, to jump dramatically. Possibly approaching that % which Nicola Sturgeon allowed the media to speculate back in  was the threshold for calling a repeat referendum.But its going to be messy. There is already disquiet in the party and in the wider Yes movement at the SNP leaders apparent lack of enthusiasm for leading the independence revolution. But after this Tory leadership campaign, she can be in no doubt that there has been a sea-change in attitudes to Scotland from the governing party. No more Mr Nice Guy. Scots will have to learn to love Brexit Britain or take the high road out of the Union.Yet, its a little odd that Scotland should have become such a touchstone issue in the Tory leadership race. There are hardly any Tory members in Scotland, after all, and it is they wholl be doing the voting in the campaign, which is now reaching peak empty promise as the ballot papers go out. But both contenders seem to have chosen to make the Union and Scotlands place in it central to their respective campaigns.They each claim, rather improbably, to have an almost religious attachment to the Union. Its blood-in-my-veins stuff for Hunt. The ldquomost successful Union in history according to Boris Johnson, clearly believing that the United States somehow fails to qualy as a union.Perhaps this relates to something deep in the Conservative psyche: that Great Britain needs to retain its subject nationalities to prove that it is still a going concern. Certainly, the loss of Scotland - taking with it a third of the UK landmass, most of its hydrocarbons and all of its nuclear weapons - would be a devastating blow to Brexit Britain. The UKs prestige, already diminished as a result of the three years of chaos and indecision, would take an even greater knock. It could lose its place on the UN Security Council, become an empty chair at G Summits...So, there was a bit of carrot to go along with the stick. Boris Johnson has declared himself ldquoMinister for the Union with the implication that devolution is now as important to the Prime Ministers role as First Lord of the Treasury . He is going to take Scotland well in hand, and ensure that all policies in future are stress tested for compatibility with all four nations.Jeremy Hunt too came bearing gts. Scotland is to become a ldquogreen Silicon Valley, a post-Brexit digital entrepocirct. He presumably avoided saying ldquoSilicon Glen because that would have reminded Scottish voters of what happened the last time Scotlands future was predicated on new technology, back in the days when the Tory George Younger ran the Scottish Office.At its height, in the early s, Scotlands technology industry made one third of all the computers manufactured in Europe. Not any more. They went where as the UK de-industrialised under Margaret Thatcher. Mr Hunt also hyped his proposal to slash corporation tax to .% - something Alex Salmond used to argue for. However, this is a policy for the UK as a whole, not Scotland, so there is no obvious comparative advantage, still less any promised to devolve business taxes.But the headline message from both Tory candidates in the Perth hustings was withering contempt for the independence movement. This will no doubt please Conservative members in the southern shires, who have already largely given up on Scotland and regard the Union with pointed indference. As YouGov discovered recently, the vast majority would willingly let Scotland goit meant saving Brexit.They may get their way sooner than they think.

title: feel-like-meet-elvis
story: Itrsquos an enduring memory and something Irsquoll never forget. My cousin Jerome and I were told that when we were in Paris [in ] that there were two clubs we should go to. One was the Folies Bergegravere and the other was the Lido.We had no booking, we were very naive so we went to the door of the Lido and askedwe could have two seats. He said we can only sit you at the bar. My cousin slipped him a few bucks and that took us about half way down and they sat us there.There was a bit pole in front of us and again, after some more bribery and corruption, we ended up at the very front table.: What does it feel like to be a lollipop man She said he had been there the previous night and was on leave from the army in Germany.When it came to the interval we were told that Elvis was coming in for the second show and to keep a couple of seats for him.When the lights went down, lo and behold, in he came with a young lady. title: issue-day-kylie-brings-magic-edinburgh-castle

title: msps-call-uk-government-halt-universal-credit-pilot
story: Bob Doris, convener of Holyroodrsquos Social Security Committee, accused the Department for Work and Pensionsof ldquoeffectively punishing people for going to their work.His committee has repeatedly raised concerns around the implementation of the new benefits system, which has been blamed for pushing Scots into rent arrears and exacerbating poverty.:Less than half of Universal Credit claimants have rent paid directly to landlordsEarlier this year, Work and Pensions Secretary Amber Rudd confirmed that claimants in Harrogate, North Yorkshire, who still receive the old-style benefits will be the first to be moved to Universal Credit under a pilot scheme starting this month.Those who lodge new claims or whose circumstances change are already receiving payments under the new system, which merges six benefits into one monthly sum.But Mr Doris warned the scheme has been ldquolittered with mistakes since being introduced in , and insisted the latest pilot should be scrapped before it is rolled out UK-wide.He also raised concerns over ldquoin-work conditionality, which critics insist sees some low-paid workers who claim Universal Credit potentially subject to sanctions unless they seek more hours or another job. The DWP argues sanctions are only used as a last resort.Mr Doris said: ldquoWe are deeply concerned that despite raising this issue as part of the Committeersquos In-Work Poverty Inquiry with the DWP in January, and the UK Governmentrsquos failure to appear at our Committee to give evidence, they have carried on with plans for implementation regardless.ldquoThis movement represents a huge cultural sht and we do not believe it is right to sanction the working poor, effectively punishing people for going to their work.ldquoThe DWP has said they are currently taking a lsquolight touchrsquo approach to in-work conditionality or sanctions but there is little confidence that when the system rolls out more widely that low paid and part-time workers wonrsquot suffer as a result.ldquoThe roll-out of Universal Credit has been littered with mistakes and it is vital that this latest pilot is put on hold to ensure that there is no negative impact upon claimants who rely on this money.The Social Security Committee said the transfer of claimants to Universal Credit should not proceed until there is more clarity around what it will mean for those affected. It also stated it is opposed in principle to attaching punitive conditions to those already in work.:MSPs blame soaring rent arrears on Universal CreditLast week, a food bank in Harrogate warned it is braced for a rise in demand as a result of the pilot, which will see long-term benefits claimants shted to the new system for the first time.Claimants usually have to wait up to five weeks for their first payment under Universal Credit, but this has been reduced to two and a half weeks for the Harrogate roll-out.Critics have blamed this delay for pushing people into poverty and debt.Lucy Stewart of the Harrogate food bank told the BBC it fed more than , people last year.She said: ldquoWe hope the process goes smoothly but the reality is that there will always be people who slip through the net of this pilot.ldquoWersquore likely to see an increase in demand for food, because people moving across to the new system are going to spend three weeks without any income.The DWP said there are now more than two million claimants receiving Universal Credit and service improvements continue to be introduced.It said the Harrogate pilot will begin this month and last for at least a year, and will be subject to ldquofull and rigorous internal governance.In addition, the DWP said it has committed toto the Commons with its findings before making wider changes.It said there are no immediate plans to expand the latest pilot into Scotland.A spokesman said: ldquoWe are taking a measured approach to moving people to Universal Credit from the old system, working with expert stakeholders to ensure vulnerable and complex claimants are fully supported.ldquoWe will also consult with Parliament before extending the process to more people.

title: plea-home-office-not-deport-arran-businesswoman-rejected

and has worked tirelessly far and beyond the realm of duty pushing for a favourable outcome."The volume of support received is a true indication of the spirit of heart within a society that welcomes people from all walks of le, cultures and background, given the opportunity to not only integrate in a community but become part of and loved.": New PMs multi-million pound war chest to crush independencePatricia Gibson MP was denied a face-to-face meeting with the immigration minister Caroline Nokes over the case but branded the treatment of the Arran resident as an "embarrassment."She said:ldquoIrsquom embarrassed that somebody like Lizanne has paid us the compliment of coming to Scotland to live and work and contribute to my constituency, who is held in such high esteem and affection by her community, and she is being treated like this.The Home Office said all applications "are considered on their inidual merits, on the basis of the evidence provided and in accordance with immigration rules".Zietsman can only reapply from outwith the UK and the couple believe it will by October at the earliest before she stands a chance of gaining permission to .

story: Pete Wishart issued the warning as he discussed theunprecedented strain between the governments in London and Edinburgh over Brexit.The chair of the Scottish Affairs Select Committee told MPs things must change dramatically to offer parity between the UK.:New PMs war chest to crush indyref hopesDuring a debate marking  years since devolution, he said: ldquoWhat we have found is that inter-governmental relations are under pressure like never before.He added: "They have been challenged within an inch of their lives by Brexit.He claimed that the relationships between the governments have not kept pace with the developments of devolution saying: ldquoThe machinery for dialogue and engagement has not kept up with the evolving dynamics of devolution.ldquoOn a sub-political level, the work between civil servants, for example, continues unabated."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Thousands take part in march in support of Scottish independence in Ayr","description": "Thousands take part in march in support of Scottish independence in Ayr","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer thumbs kDRktGq-.jpg","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests kDRktGq.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": He went on to warn any calls for a second independence referendum from the Scottish Parliament must be adhered to.He said: ldquoThis is a matter for the Scottish people. The Scottish people should always get what the Scottish people want.SNP MP Tommy Sheppard told the Commons ldquoUnionist support for devolution has been motivated by a desire to contain demands for independence and cited former Tory MP Enoch Powellrsquos dictum ldquopower devolved is power retained.:Brexit has put relations between London and Edinburgh under pressure like never before, says Pete WishartBut Sheppard went on to say that the successes of devolution had prompted many in Scotland to think about independence, particularly in light of the resistance from the UKGovernmentto hand over more powers toHolyrood.ldquoFrom drug policy to broadcasting, employment law to food standards, there is so much we would like to do but cannot because of the constraints of the current devolution arrangements, he said.ldquoItrsquos worth stating that this is not necessarily an argument for independence. All the things Irsquove just listed could be achieved through further devolution.ldquoBut what is so remarkable is that those who once claimed the legacy of the home-rulers refuse to countenance a single further power being devolved. A bill is going through Holyrood to set out the rules for the vote.:Noel Gallagher: Scotland like a third world countryHowever, Prime MinisterTheresa Mayand the two contenders to succeed her,Boris Johnsonand Jeremy Hunt, are opposed to a new independence referendum.A number of polls have suggested support for independence would riseJohnson becomes PM, with one last month indicating it would be around %.In the Commons Cabinet Office minister, Kevin Foster dismissed a survey of Tory members which suggested % believed Brexit was more important than keeping the UK together, saying: ldquoIrsquom a Unionist and I want to see this Union remain together. That poll is absolute rubbish.Labourrsquos Paul Sweeney said some powers Holyrood had to change income tax or welfare were not being used, adding: ldquoThe existing powers of the Scottish Parliament must be used effectively ndash that being said, new powers may well be needed to make a real dference in tackling the problems [Scotland faces].This article appeared in our sister paper The National
